newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EC eyes France Telecom funds transfer to state.
newsitem.headline: EC eyes France Telecom funds transfer to state.

text.p: The European Commission is looking at whether a transfer of funds from France Telecom to the state to cover pension liabilities could be considered as revenue when calculating France's budget deficit next year, a Commission official said on Wednesday.

"The French have given us a presentation that is based on principles of European accounting that we recognise but we have not taken a final position on it. But we certainly have not dismissed it out of hand," the official said.
He said he was not sure when the Commission would make a ruling on the question, saying there was unlikely to be a firm decision in the very near future.

The French government has said that some 37.5 billion francs will be transferred from France Telecom to the state next year in return for the state assuming its pension liabilities ahead of its partial privatisation.

Telecommunications Minister Francois Fillon said this money could be considered as revenue when it comes to calculating France's total budget deficit next year under the terms of the Maastricht treaty on European monetary union.

While the funds would nonetheless be earmarked for future pension payments, their inclusion in the calculation of the size of the budget deficit could prove crucial in allowing France to reduce its deficit to three percent of gross domestic product next year to meet Maastricht treaty goals for entry into European monetary union in 1999.

Finance ministry sources have said that while the government believes the France Telecom transfer could be considered as revenue as defined by the Maastricht treaty, no decision had yet been taken as to how exactly the funds would be allocated.
